Description: A double-ended stamp for decorating Egyptian Red Slip A pottery bowls and plates, it is circular and waisted, flaring to each end, with one end larger than the other. The larger end has an interlace pattern flanked by a double curve and a monogram of rho and epsilon. The other end has an uncertain radiating device perhaps including rhos. There is slight damage in several places. Hand-modelled; decoration probably made by incision in the leather-hard clay. Micaceous orange Aswan clay, with an overall thin matt red slip.
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Purchased: Robert de Rustafjaell Sale, 1906. Late Roman, about AD 500-600. Bibliog: Not recognized in Sotheby's 'Sale Catalogue', 19-21 December 1906.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3596)
